snippet: Years ago, cab drivers didn’t have to rent their cabs or pay for gas, but now they are “independent contractors,” a winsome way of saying they are carrying most of the risk.
abstract: Michael Powell Gotham column commends Mayor Michael R Bloomberg for fighting to raise wages for New York City taxi drivers, but says he faces a hard fight against the politically-connected taxicab industry; notes that years ago drivers did not have to rent their cabs or pay for gas, but now, as independent contractors, the burden of a slow night of work falls heavily on the drivers, making it difficult to earn a living.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, cab drivers didn’t have to rent their cabs or pay for gas, but now they are “independent contractors,” a winsome way of saying they are carrying most of the risk.

headline.seo: As Pay of Cabbies Drops, a Bid for Their First Raise in Years
headline.main: Their Meters Keep Running, but the Fares Barely Make Ends Meet
headline.print_headline: Their Meters Keep Running, but the Fares Barely Make Ends Meet
